dataset.title: Ant-plant dynamics: the effects of leaves and scale insects on ant species richness and abundance on Acacia grandicornuta and Acacia robusta

abstract.para: In this study, we examined whether leaf presence affected ant abundances on Acacia grandicornuta, and how the presence of scale insects on Acacia robusta affected ant species abundance. In order to asses the benefits accrued by the plants, we also tested attack times of three genera of ants following a disturbance to the host tree. It was determined that both ant species richness and concentration were significantly greater on A. grandicornuta containing leaves. This result suggests that the presence of leaves drives the mutualism between A. grandicornuta and ants, and when leaves are not present, ant concentrations decrease. We also determined that Black Sugar Ants (Lepisiota capensis) exist in greater abundance on A. robusta when scale insects are present, and this populace of L. capensis correlates to a reduction in the abundance of other ant species. Finally, our results show that L. capensis attack significantly quicker than other ant genera following a disturbance to the host tree. This demonstrates the ability of L. capensis to colonize and dominate a host tree, causing a significant decrease in the abundance of other ant genera. These results convey that a facultative mutualism exists among A. robusta, L. capensis, and scale insects; L. capensis provides protection for both A. robusta and scale insects, while scale insects offer nutritional benefits to the resident ants.

keywordSet.keyword: Acacia grandicornuta,, Acacia robusta,ant-plant mutualism,Lepisiota capensis,scale insects

section.title: Site selection and Field sampling
section.para: This study was conducted in and around the Skukuza rest camp of Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga province, South Africa (24°98” S 31°60” E). We conducted and performed all field work for our study and subsequent experiment over the course of a three day period from October 10, 2005 to October 12, 2005, near the end of the dry season.

Our study species were Acacia grandicornuta and Acacia robusta. A. grandicornuta is a medium-sized tree with deep fissured bark and paired, short thorns, and is often found on either sodic or clay soils throughout the north-eastern region of South Africa. A. grandicornuta is tolerant of dry conditions and is normally leafless from August to October. A. robusta is a single-stemmed tree with paired, straight, modified stipules as thorns and an annual leaf presence. A. robusta tends to grow throughout the north-eastern region of South Africa, typically near a water source and it rarely occurs in homogeneous stands. Neither A. grandicornuta nor A. robusta are known to produce extra floral nectaries, food bodies or beltian bodies (Smit 1999).

We examined 26 Acacia grandicornuta individuals—12 possessing leaves and 14 lacking leaves—all located in and around the staff village of the Skukuza main camp, primarily near the golf course. We chose to observe A. grandicornuta in order to compare the status of this facultative ant-plant mutualism when leaves were present and absent. This was possible as A. grandicornuta loses its leaves from late August to early October, thus yielding a sufficient abundance of individuals with and without leaves. We then examined 14 Acacia robusta individuals—all of which possessed leaves.

For each A. grandicornuta and A. robusta individual encountered, we recorded a number of observations: the average abundance of ants, ant species composition, the presence or absence of scale insects, and the degree of defensive behavior of the ants on each tree. The abundance of ants on each tree was obtained by selecting two .25m by .5m sections, estimating the number of ants per section, and averaging the two abundance measures. We identified our ant samples down to genus, and in one instance down to species. Following our initial study, we conducted a subsequent experiment in which we generated an artificial disturbance. To mimic natural herbivory processes we scratched the trunk of the tree while simultaneously shaking a branch.

Mann-Whitney U-tests were performed to test for significant differences in ant abundance dependent on leaf presence and scale insect presence in A. grandicornuta and A. robusta respectively. A Kruskal-Wallis test was conducted to determine differences in attack time among three ant genera.
